title: 109_s2205
content: The Act titled "Blunt Reservoir and Pierre Canal Land Conveyance Act of 2006" is about the conveyance of land related to Blunt Reservoir and Pierre Canal. The Blunt Reservoir feature and Pierre Canal feature are defined in the Act as part of the Pick-Sloan Missouri River Basin program. The Commission refers to the Commission of Schools and Public Lands of the State. Nonpreferential lease parcels are land parcels purchased by the Secretary for use in connection with the features. The Pierre Canal feature is part of the Oahe Unit, James Division, authorized by the Act of August 3, 1968. A preferential leaseholder is someone who held a lease on a preferential lease parcel as of January 1, 2001. A preferential lease parcel is a land parcel considered nonpreferential by the Secretary as of January 1, 2001. A "leaseholder" is a person or descendant who held a lease on a preferential lease parcel as of January 1, 2001. A "preferential lease parcel" is land purchased by the Secretary for use in connection with the Blunt Reservoir or Pierre Canal features. The "Secretary" refers to the Secretary of the Interior, and "State" means the State of South Dakota. The Blunt Reservoir feature is deauthorized, and unleased parcels are defined as land not under lease purchased for the Blunt Reservoir or Pierre Canal features. The State of South Dakota may accept land and obligations as part of conveyances. The Blunt Reservoir feature is deauthorized, and the State of South Dakota may accept land and obligations as part of conveyances, including liability for ownership, operation, and maintenance of certain features. The State of South Dakota may accept land and obligations related to ownership, operation, and maintenance of certain features, including liability for expired easements and rights granted. The Commission will act as the agent for the Secretary in administering purchase options for preferential leaseholders. Outstanding obligations will be binding upon the State, and conveyances will be subject to reserved oil, gas, and mineral rights. The State of South Dakota may accept land and obligations related to ownership, operation, and maintenance of certain features, including liability for expired easements and rights granted. Conveyances to the State will be subject to reserved oil, gas, and mineral rights, as well as any outstanding permits, licenses, leases, or rights-of-way held by third parties. The State of South Dakota may accept land with obligations related to ownership, operation, and maintenance, subject to reserved rights and conditions specified in the Act of May 19, 1948. Preferential leaseholders have an option to purchase the lease parcel under certain terms. Preferential leaseholders have the option to purchase the lease parcel under certain terms, including a cash purchase option. The value of the parcel for preferential leaseholders is determined under specific terms, with a ten percent deduction. The preferential leaseholder can purchase the parcel in installments, with 10 percent paid upfront and the rest over 30 years at 3 percent interest. If the parcel is under $10,000, the purchase must be made in cash. The leaseholder has 5 years to exercise the purchase option. Until then, they can continue leasing the parcel under the same terms. The preferential leaseholder has 5 years after enactment to exercise the purchase option. They can continue leasing the parcel under the same terms until then. The value of the parcel is determined by fair market value for agricultural purposes, minus 25 percent. The fair market value of a property is determined by an independent appraisal less 25 percent, in accordance with federal regulations. Any disputes over value are resolved as per specific regulations. If a preferential leaseholder fails to purchase a parcel within the specified time, it may be offered to the State of South Dakota Department of Game, Fish, and Parks. If a preferential leaseholder fails to purchase a parcel within the specified time, the Secretary will offer to convey the parcel to the State of South Dakota Department of Game, Fish, and Parks for wildlife habitat mitigation. Proceeds from land sales will be deposited as miscellaneous funds in the Treasury for the establishment of a trust fund to pay county taxes on the lands received by the State Department of Game, Fish, and Parks. Proceeds from land sales under the Pick-Sloan project will be deposited as miscellaneous funds in the Treasury to establish a trust fund for paying county taxes on lands received by the South Dakota Department of Game, Fish, and Parks. The Secretary will offer to convey nonpreferential lease parcels and unleased parcels of the Blunt Reservoir and Pierre Canal to the South Dakota Department of Game, Fish, and Parks for wildlife habitat mitigation within one year of the enactment of the Act. The Secretary will offer to convey nonpreferential lease parcels and unleased parcels of the Blunt Reservoir and Pierre Canal to the South Dakota Department of Game, Fish, and Parks for wildlife habitat mitigation. Land exchanges may be allowed for these parcels with the concurrence of the South Dakota Department of Game, Fish, and Parks. The South Dakota Commission of Schools and Public Lands may allow land exchanges at Blunt Reservoir or Pierre Canal with the concurrence of the South Dakota Department of Game, Fish, and Parks. Priority is given to current lessees and adjoining landowners for nonpreferential lease parcels and unleased parcels. Easements for water conveyance structures are also included. The South Dakota Commission of Schools and Public Lands may allow land exchanges at Blunt Reservoir or Pierre Canal with priority given to current lessees and adjoining landowners for nonpreferential lease parcels and unleased parcels. A perpetual easement is reserved for water conveyance structures over the Pierre Canal feature. The United States shall not be held liable upon conveyance of any parcel under this Act. The United States can construct, operate, maintain, repair, and replace a pipeline or water conveyance structure over the Pierre Canal. Upon conveyance of any parcel under this Act, the United States is released from liability for damages, except for acts of negligence. There are no additional liabilities under the Federal Tort Claims Act. During the interim period, the Secretary must continue leasing preferential and nonpreferential parcels under existing terms. Parcel descriptions must be provided within 180 days of the Act's enactment. The Secretary will transfer archeological collections to the South Dakota State Historical Society without cost. $750,000 is authorized for the Act's implementation. The Secretary will transfer archeological and cultural items to the South Dakota State Historical Society at no cost. $750,000 is authorized for implementing the Act, with additional funds available to reimburse expenses incurred by the Commission and State Department of Game, Fish, and Parks, not exceeding 10% of transaction costs.
